org.gearvrf.animation

Class GVRRepeatMode

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.animation.GVRRepeatMode

  • public abstract class GVRRepeatMode
extends java.lang.Object
    The three supported repeat modes.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int ONCE
      Run once.
      static int PINGPONG
      Run repeatedly: start to finish, finish to start; start to finish, finish to start; and so on.
      static int REPEATED
      Run repeatedly: start to finish; start to finish; and so on.

    • Field Detail

      • ONCE

        public static final int ONCE
        Run once. This is the default: setRepeatMode() lets you specify either of the alternatives. Run-once will leave the animated property in the 'new' state, which is normally what you want: you use a run-once animation to smooth a transition.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REPEATED

        public static final int REPEATED
        Run repeatedly: start to finish; start to finish; and so on. This will leave the animated property in the 'start' state. In some cases, this will be visually jarring; in others (like when you are doing a full 360 degree rotation) this will be exactly what you want.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PINGPONG

        public static final int PINGPONG
        Run repeatedly: start to finish, finish to start; start to finish, finish to start; and so on. This is perfect for 'wiggle' or grow-shrink animations. Note that an odd repeat count will leave the animated property in the 'new' state, just like run-once does; an even repeat count will leave the animated property in the 'start' state, just like repeated does. The default repeat count is 2, so you don't have to explicitly set a repeat count to 'pulse' an object with a ping pong animation.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • GVRRepeatMode

        public GVRRepeatMode()
